data.text:
I thought I would post this rather amusing story that happened this evening...

Went to catch the 1815 train from Slade Green to Abbey Wood and standing outside the station entrance were a couple of youths.

These delightful souls thought it would be nice to call me a few choice rude words and spit at me as I entered the path leading up to platform 1.

I ignored them, tapped my Oyster card in and boarded the train a few coaches down (as it was a ten coach train).

Just past Erith a couple of ticket inspectors were making their way down the train and I got my Oyster card checked and they went off on their merry way.

I got off at Abbey Wood, crossed the footbridge and much to my amusement I could see on the opposite platform being led off by the two ticket inspectors were the same two youths who were standing outside Slade Green calling me names and spitting!

I somehow suspect they didn't have a valid ticket of any sort - never know they may soon post on these very forums to get some advice!!!

Just goes to show, what goes around does indeed come around

That made my day

Blakey

They should never have been able to get on a train in the first place, where they were probably hassling more people. If only TfL had taken over and manned all stations and put in barriers - it would help stop things like this.

With Slade Green unstaffed and no barriers in use, 99 times out of 100 they wont be stopped and will put others off using railways.

You mean like those stations on the NLL or GOBLIN that have no ticket barriers? There is no guarantee if TfL take over barriers will be put in.

Anti social behavior is not uncommon in that area, I'm surprised they were compliant with ticket inspectors. Did you report the spitting incident to BTP? They could well end up in court on an assault charge.

You mean like those stations on the NLL or GOBLIN that have no ticket barriers? There is no guarantee if TfL take over barriers will be put in.

No guarantee at every station, but since TfL have taken over various lines they've installed barriers and staffing at the vast majority. Including many with far less passengers per annum than most stations on SE metro routes.

Those stations on LO that havn't are either lightly used or are impractical, but with most stations covered there's a high chance that even if someone gets on without passing barriers, they can't get off. Not so with 90% un-barriered on SE. If they deemed 600k users not enough at Slade Green (and that is an underestimate with avoidance so easy) then most others would very likely be covered with more than 1m per year.

Anti social behavior is not uncommon in that area, I'm surprised they were compliant with ticket inspectors. Did you report the spitting incident to BTP? They could well end up in court on an assault charge.

Unfortunately the friendly local youths were outside the station property at the time, I didn't actually realise they intended on travelling - so I didn't report anything. and often that's exactly what they want you to do is provoke them which is why I just ignored their stupidity and got on the train.

I thought I would post this rather amusing story that happened this evening...

That made my day

Blakey

Of course no-one should have to put up with such behaviour; but may I congratulate you on the way you have dealt with it.

......TfL have recently taken over........ If (hopefully when) they take over SE metro then I would expect the same to apply.

Do you really think that South Eastern suburban network needs the added burden of carrying Elderly etc. passengers, for free, in the peaks? If they could be accommodated without consequences that might be all fine and dandy, but I can only see more standing passengers being the result. There is little or no scope for more trains to be run.

No guarantee at every station, but since TfL have taken over various lines they've installed barriers and staffing at the vast majority. Including many with far less passengers per annum than most stations on SE metro routes.

Those stations on LO that havn't are either lightly used or are impractical, but with most stations covered there's a high chance that even if someone gets on without passing barriers, they can't get off. Not so with 90% un-barriered on SE. If they deemed 600k users not enough at Slade Green (and that is an underestimate with avoidance so easy) then most others would very likely be covered with more than 1m per year.

LO also have LOTS of revenue inspectors out on a regular basis....

I wonder then how TfL manages to operate the DLR with no station staff, no barriers, and in my experience a pretty complete freedom from yobs.

I get my ticket/oyster checked on average on about a quarter of journeys, and of course many journeys start or end at gated stations which helps too (I live in the Docklands) (Bank, Woolwich Arsenal, Stratford, West Ham and Canning Town are fully gated).

The reason there are no barriers and no station staff is because it was designed to be an almost minimal cost system. It was originally conceived as a mostly-segregated tramway. When automatic trains became the favoured option (cheaper than drivers) the northern branch was rerouted from terminating on-street at Mile End to run fully segregated to Stratford.

As for yobs, much of the area the DLR serves has undergone massive gentrification, but even those areas that haven't tend not to see too many yobs on the train. I can only assume this is due to the member of staff on board who can devote their attention to removing them if necessary.

--- old post above --- --- new post below ---

Do you really think that South Eastern suburban network needs the added burden of carrying Elderly etc. passengers, for free, in the peaks? If they could be accommodated without consequences that might be all fine and dandy, but I can only see more standing passengers being the result. There is little or no scope for more trains to be run.

Even if the free travel in the peaks is extended to the SE metro, I doubt that a significant number of people will make use of it simply because the trains are so full already. The biggest benefits of TfL will be fare harmonisation (it shouldn't cost more to travel from Woolwich to Greenwich direct than via Poplar and Canary Wharf for example), an operator who actually cares about providing a metro service and some actual effort at minor stations. Southeastern projects a distinct "couldn't give a damn" atmosphere onto their metro routes.

They should never have been able to get on a train in the first place, where they were probably hassling more people. If only TfL had taken over and manned all stations and put in barriers - it would help stop things like this.

With Slade Green unstaffed and no barriers in use, 99 times out of 100 they wont be stopped and will put others off using railways.

But all of this happened outside of the station and I still see this happen at LO stations at night when I use them - how effect do you think station staff are to prevent something not on their property? And it isn't confined to just SE metro lines - it occurs all over the country.

IAs for yobs, much of the area the DLR serves has undergone massive gentrification, but even those areas that haven't tend not to see too many yobs on the train. I can only assume this is due to the member of staff on board who can devote their attention to removing them if necessary.

Not wholly true - it is still a massive issue especially on the southern and eastern to WOA routes.

I wonder then how TfL manages to operate the DLR with no station staff, no barriers, and in my experience a pretty complete freedom from yobs.

A member of staff walking through each train, and FAR more regular patrols of RPIs.

--- old post above --- --- new post below ---

It isn't a fact. Southeastern are required to staff 40 gatelines and according to Wiki call at 179 stations. That would make at least 22% of stations gated on SE. A further 2 stations are required to be gated during the Direct Award period.

Like Abbey Wood, mentioned in the first post, that is technically gated but has a side entrance open and unmanned all day, every day?

There's very few that are manned all day - London terminals mainly and stations like Lewisham and Dartford, though even then often only until 8pm.

--- old post above --- --- new post below ---

Really ? Wow that is an interesting fact. Can you back that up with evidence ?

Daily use for 20 years, with work taking me to various stations 5 days a week? Plus, staff I know back it up regarding evasion levels. Maybe some on here could comment?

If we take the line mentioned - from Cannon Street to Dartford you would have only 2 stations manned all day - those being Cannon Street and London Bridge. The other 13 wouldn't. Woolwich Arsenal & Dartford until 8pm perhaps but not all day. If talking of the route to Medway it'd be around another 6+ that are open part, or all day.

--- old post above --- --- new post below ---

I see this line line is blocked right now due to disruptive passengers at Charlton. Emergency services en route.

There are push-bar exit gates which can only be opened from the platform side. Although they are supposed to be for emergency use only, I regularly saw people use them as a normal exit and no-one took any notice of the alarm.

Then folk will wait by these for someone to come out and sneak in, as they seem to do happily and without enforcement all the time on the Paris Metro - even on the main Gare du Nord concourse. Annulling the whole point.

I would strongly favour manning any closed barrier system full time, given how often I have seen and experienced problems at these requiring manual intervention.

If one reported every act of anti-social behaviour to the police then one would be spending an awful amount of one's week so doing. This applies probably in most urban environments now, not just in my old stamping ground of S.E. London. Two days ago in my adopted home town of Penzance I was issued with a threat of death from a choice individual in combat jacket with an alsatian by his side as he deliberately barged into me in the street. I chose not to attempt to take it any further, being about thirty years older than him and knowing it would not end satisfactorily from my point of view. Yes, I am frustrated, even angry, at this state of affairs but it is the reality of where we are as a society.

Why can't people just be honest and buy a ticket.

a) they think the service is rubbish, so why bother paying for a ticket

b) they cannot afford a ticket but still want to travel

c) they want to buy a ticket but cannot

d) they have seen that they can get away with it so have stopped

e) their friends/colleagues/school classmates do it too so they will do it too

...this could go all the way to z) I think!
